trans-unit.source: Create a MongoDB cluster on Ubuntu using a Azure Resource Manager template
trans-unit.target: Create a MongoDB cluster on Ubuntu using a Azure Resource Manager template

trans-unit.source: Create a MongoDB cluster on Ubuntu using a Azure Resource Manager template via Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Create a MongoDB cluster on Ubuntu using a Azure Resource Manager template via Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: MongoDB is an open-source document database that provides high performance, high availability, and automatic scaling.
trans-unit.target: MongoDB is an open-source document database that provides high performance, high availability, and automatic scaling.

trans-unit.source: MongoDB can be installed as a stand-alone database or within a cluster, leveraging built-in replication capabilities.
trans-unit.target: MongoDB can be installed as a stand-alone database or within a cluster, leveraging built-in replication capabilities.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, you can use replication to increase read capacity.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, you can use replication to increase read capacity.

trans-unit.source: Clients have the ability to send read and write operations to different servers.
trans-unit.target: Clients have the ability to send read and write operations to different servers.

trans-unit.source: You can also maintain copies in different data centers to increase the locality and availability of data for distributed applications.
trans-unit.target: You can also maintain copies in different data centers to increase the locality and availability of data for distributed applications.

trans-unit.source: With MongoDB, replication also provides redundancy and increases data availability.
trans-unit.target: With MongoDB, replication also provides redundancy and increases data availability.

trans-unit.source: With multiple copies of data on different database servers, replication protects a database from the loss of a single server.
trans-unit.target: With multiple copies of data on different database servers, replication protects a database from the loss of a single server.

trans-unit.source: Replication also allows you to recover from hardware failure and service interruptions.
trans-unit.target: Replication also allows you to recover from hardware failure and service interruptions.

trans-unit.source: With additional copies of the data, you can dedicate one to disaster recovery, reporting, or backup.
trans-unit.target: With additional copies of the data, you can dedicate one to disaster recovery, reporting, or backup.

trans-unit.source: In addition to the various flavors that were already available in the Azure Marketplace, now you can also easily deploy a new MongoDB cluster on Ubuntu VMs using a Azure Resource Manager template deployed through <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the various flavors that were already available in the Azure Marketplace, now you can also easily deploy a new MongoDB cluster on Ubuntu VMs using a Azure Resource Manager template deployed through <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Newly deployed clusters based on this template will have the topology described in the following diagram, although other topologies can be easily achieved by customizing the template presented in this article.
trans-unit.target: Newly deployed clusters based on this template will have the topology described in the following diagram, although other topologies can be easily achieved by customizing the template presented in this article.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>cluster-architecture</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>cluster-architecture</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Through a parameter you can define the number of nodes that will be deployed in the new MongoDB cluster and, based on another parameter, a VM instance (Jumpbox) with a public IP address may be also deployed within the same VNET, giving you the ability to connect to the cluster from public Internet and perform any sort of administrative task related that cluster.
trans-unit.target: Through a parameter you can define the number of nodes that will be deployed in the new MongoDB cluster and, based on another parameter, a VM instance (Jumpbox) with a public IP address may be also deployed within the same VNET, giving you the ability to connect to the cluster from public Internet and perform any sort of administrative task related that cluster.

trans-unit.source: Another option available as a parameter, is the ability to add an Arbiter node to the replica set, that is typically suggested when that has an even number of members.
trans-unit.target: Another option available as a parameter, is the ability to add an Arbiter node to the replica set, that is typically suggested when that has an even number of members.

trans-unit.source: For more information on MongoDB replication topologies and details, see the official <linkText>MongoDB documentation</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on MongoDB replication topologies and details, see the official <linkText>MongoDB documentation</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once the deployment is complete you can access the Jumpbox using the configured DNS address on SSH port 22.
trans-unit.target: Once the deployment is complete you can access the Jumpbox using the configured DNS address on SSH port 22.

trans-unit.source: Before diving into more details related to the Azure Resource Manager and the template we will use for this deployment, make sure you have Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI configured correctly.
trans-unit.target: Before diving into more details related to the Azure Resource Manager and the template we will use for this deployment, make sure you have Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI configured correctly.

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to create a MongoDB cluster using a Resource Manager template from the Github template repository.
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to create a MongoDB cluster using a Resource Manager template from the Github template repository.

trans-unit.source: Each step will include directions for both Azure PowerShell and the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Each step will include directions for both Azure PowerShell and the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: Create a local folder for the JSON template and other associated files (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\MongoDB).
trans-unit.target: Create a local folder for the JSON template and other associated files (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\MongoDB).

trans-unit.source: In the following example, substitute the folder name of your local folder and run the commands.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, substitute the folder name of your local folder and run the commands.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to clone the entire template repository using a Git client of your choice.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to clone the entire template repository using a Git client of your choice.

trans-unit.source: When completed, look for the mongodb-high-availability folder in your C:\Azure\Templates directory.
trans-unit.target: When completed, look for the mongodb-high-availability folder in your C:\Azure\Templates directory.

trans-unit.source: When you deploy non-trivial solutions like a MongoDB cluster, you must specify a set of configuration parameters to deal with a number of required settings.
trans-unit.target: When you deploy non-trivial solutions like a MongoDB cluster, you must specify a set of configuration parameters to deal with a number of required settings.

trans-unit.source: By declaring these parameters in the template definition, it’s possible to specify values during deployment through an external file or in the command line.
trans-unit.target: By declaring these parameters in the template definition, it’s possible to specify values during deployment through an external file or in the command line.

trans-unit.source: In the parameters section at the top of the azuredeploy.json file, you’ll find the set of parameters that are required by the template to configure a MongoDB cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the parameters section at the top of the azuredeploy.json file, you’ll find the set of parameters that are required by the template to configure a MongoDB cluster.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the parameters section from this template's azuredeploy.json file.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the parameters section from this template's azuredeploy.json file.

trans-unit.source: Each parameter has details such as data type and allowed values.
trans-unit.target: Each parameter has details such as data type and allowed values.

trans-unit.source: This allows for validation of parameters passed during template execution in an interactive mode (for example, PowerShell or Azure CLI), as well as a self-discovery UI that could be dynamically-built by parsing the list of required parameters and their descriptions.
trans-unit.target: This allows for validation of parameters passed during template execution in an interactive mode (for example, PowerShell or Azure CLI), as well as a self-discovery UI that could be dynamically-built by parsing the list of required parameters and their descriptions.

trans-unit.source: Prepare a parameters file for your deployment by creating a JSON file containing runtime values for all parameters.
trans-unit.target: Prepare a parameters file for your deployment by creating a JSON file containing runtime values for all parameters.

trans-unit.source: This file will then be passed as a single entity to the deployment command.
trans-unit.target: This file will then be passed as a single entity to the deployment command.

trans-unit.source: If you do not include a parameters file, PowerShell will use any default values specified in the template, and then prompt you to fill in the remaining values.
trans-unit.target: If you do not include a parameters file, PowerShell will use any default values specified in the template, and then prompt you to fill in the remaining values.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the set of parameters from the azuredeploy-parameters.json file.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the set of parameters from the azuredeploy-parameters.json file.

trans-unit.source: Fill in an Azure deployment name, resource group name, Azure location, and the folder of your saved JSON deployment file.
trans-unit.target: Fill in an Azure deployment name, resource group name, Azure location, and the folder of your saved JSON deployment file.

trans-unit.source: Then run the following commands.
trans-unit.target: Then run the following commands.

trans-unit.source: When you run the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command, this will extract parameter values from the JSON parameters file, and will start executing the template accordingly.
trans-unit.target: When you run the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command, this will extract parameter values from the JSON parameters file, and will start executing the template accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Defining and using multiple parameter files with your different environments (for example, Test, Production, etc.)
trans-unit.target: Defining and using multiple parameter files with your different environments (for example, Test, Production, etc.)

trans-unit.source: will promote template reuse and simplify complex multi-environment solutions.
trans-unit.target: will promote template reuse and simplify complex multi-environment solutions.

trans-unit.source: When deploying, keep in mind that a new Azure storage account needs to be created so the name you provide as the storage account parameter must be unique and meet all requirements for an Azure storage account (lowercase letters and numbers only).
trans-unit.target: When deploying, keep in mind that a new Azure storage account needs to be created so the name you provide as the storage account parameter must be unique and meet all requirements for an Azure storage account (lowercase letters and numbers only).

trans-unit.source: During and after deployment, you can check all the requests that were made during provisioning, including any errors that occurred.
trans-unit.target: During and after deployment, you can check all the requests that were made during provisioning, including any errors that occurred.

trans-unit.source: To do that, go to the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title> and do the following:
trans-unit.target: To do that, go to the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title> and do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click Browse on the left navigation bar, scroll down and then click Resource Groups.
trans-unit.target: Click Browse on the left navigation bar, scroll down and then click Resource Groups.

trans-unit.source: After clicking the resource group that you just created, it will bring up the Resource group blade.
trans-unit.target: After clicking the resource group that you just created, it will bring up the Resource group blade.

trans-unit.source: By clicking the "Events” bar graph in the "Monitoring” part of the Resource group blade, you can see the events for your deployment.
trans-unit.target: By clicking the "Events” bar graph in the "Monitoring” part of the Resource group blade, you can see the events for your deployment.

trans-unit.source: Clicking an individual event lets you drill further down into the details of each individual operation made on behalf of the template.
trans-unit.target: Clicking an individual event lets you drill further down into the details of each individual operation made on behalf of the template.

trans-unit.source: After your tests, if you need to remove this resource group and all of its resources (the storage account, virtual machine, and virtual network), use the following command.
trans-unit.target: After your tests, if you need to remove this resource group and all of its resources (the storage account, virtual machine, and virtual network), use the following command.

trans-unit.source: To deploy a MongoDB cluster via the Azure CLI, first create a resource group by specifying a name and a location with the following command.
trans-unit.target: To deploy a MongoDB cluster via the Azure CLI, first create a resource group by specifying a name and a location with the following command.

trans-unit.source: Pass this resource group name, the location of the JSON template file, and the location of the parameters file (see the earlier PowerShell section for details) into the following command.
trans-unit.target: Pass this resource group name, the location of the JSON template file, and the location of the parameters file (see the earlier PowerShell section for details) into the following command.

trans-unit.source: You can check the status of individual resources deployments with the following command.
trans-unit.target: You can check the status of individual resources deployments with the following command.

trans-unit.source: To design a robust and reusable Azure Resource Manager template, additional thinking is needed to organize the series of complex and interrelated tasks required during the deployment of a complex solution like MongoDB.
trans-unit.target: To design a robust and reusable Azure Resource Manager template, additional thinking is needed to organize the series of complex and interrelated tasks required during the deployment of a complex solution like MongoDB.

trans-unit.source: Leveraging Azure Resource Manager template linking and resource looping in addition to script execution through related extensions, it’s possible to implement a modular approach that can be reused with virtually any complex template-based deployment.
trans-unit.target: Leveraging Azure Resource Manager template linking and resource looping in addition to script execution through related extensions, it’s possible to implement a modular approach that can be reused with virtually any complex template-based deployment.

trans-unit.source: The following diagram describes the relationships between all the files downloaded from GitHub for this deployment.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram describes the relationships between all the files downloaded from GitHub for this deployment.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>mongodb-files</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>mongodb-files</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This section steps you through the structure of the azuredeploy.json file for the MongoDB cluster.
trans-unit.target: This section steps you through the structure of the azuredeploy.json file for the MongoDB cluster.

trans-unit.source: The parameters section of azuredeploy.json specifies modifiable parameters that are used in this template.
trans-unit.target: The parameters section of azuredeploy.json specifies modifiable parameters that are used in this template.

trans-unit.source: The azuredeploy-parameters.json file described earlier in this article is used to pass values into the parameters section of azuredeploy.json during template execution.
trans-unit.target: The azuredeploy-parameters.json file described earlier in this article is used to pass values into the parameters section of azuredeploy.json during template execution.

trans-unit.source: The variables section specifies variables that can be used throughout this template.
trans-unit.target: The variables section specifies variables that can be used throughout this template.

trans-unit.source: This contains a number of fields (JSON data types or fragments) that will be set to constants or calculated values at execution time.
trans-unit.target: This contains a number of fields (JSON data types or fragments) that will be set to constants or calculated values at execution time.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the variables section for this MongoDB template.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the variables section for this MongoDB template.

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, you can see two different approaches.
trans-unit.target: In the previous example, you can see two different approaches.

trans-unit.source: In this first fragment, the "osFamilyUbuntu" variable will be set to a JSON element containing 6 key value pairs.
trans-unit.target: In this first fragment, the "osFamilyUbuntu" variable will be set to a JSON element containing 6 key value pairs.

trans-unit.source: In this second fragment, the "vmScripts" variable is assigned to a JSON array where single elements will be calculated at runtime using a template language function (concat) and the value of another variable plus string constants.
trans-unit.target: In this second fragment, the "vmScripts" variable is assigned to a JSON array where single elements will be calculated at runtime using a template language function (concat) and the value of another variable plus string constants.

trans-unit.source: One important concept in this template is the way different “t-shirt sizes” for MongoDB clusters are defined.
trans-unit.target: One important concept in this template is the way different “t-shirt sizes” for MongoDB clusters are defined.

trans-unit.source: Looking at one of those “tshirtSizeXXXX” variables, you can notice that it describes important characteristics of how a cluster is deployed.
trans-unit.target: Looking at one of those “tshirtSizeXXXX” variables, you can notice that it describes important characteristics of how a cluster is deployed.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, let’s take the Medium size as an example.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, let’s take the Medium size as an example.

trans-unit.source: A “Medium” MongoDB cluster will use D2 as VM Size for the three MongoDB nodes hosting data, plus a fourth A1 VM that will be used as arbiter for replication purposes.
trans-unit.target: A “Medium” MongoDB cluster will use D2 as VM Size for the three MongoDB nodes hosting data, plus a fourth A1 VM that will be used as arbiter for replication purposes.

trans-unit.source: The corresponding sub-template invoked to deploy data nodes will be member-resources-D2.json and data files (250 GB each) will be stored in two storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: The corresponding sub-template invoked to deploy data nodes will be member-resources-D2.json and data files (250 GB each) will be stored in two storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: This variables will be used within the resources section to orchestrate node deployments and other tasks.
trans-unit.target: This variables will be used within the resources section to orchestrate node deployments and other tasks.

trans-unit.source: The resources section is where most of the action is happening.
trans-unit.target: The resources section is where most of the action is happening.

trans-unit.source: Looking carefully inside this section, you can immediately identify two different cases: the first one is an element defined of type Microsoft.Resources/deployments that basically means the invocation of a nested deployment within the main one.
trans-unit.target: Looking carefully inside this section, you can immediately identify two different cases: the first one is an element defined of type Microsoft.Resources/deployments that basically means the invocation of a nested deployment within the main one.

trans-unit.source: Through the "templateLink" element (and related version property), it’s possible to specify a linked template file that will be invoked passing a set of parameters as input, as shown in the next example.
trans-unit.target: Through the "templateLink" element (and related version property), it’s possible to specify a linked template file that will be invoked passing a set of parameters as input, as shown in the next example.

trans-unit.source: From the previous example, it is clear how azuredeploy.json in this scenario has been organized as a sort of orchestration mechanism, invoking a number of other template files, each one responsible for part of the required deployment activities.
trans-unit.target: From the previous example, it is clear how azuredeploy.json in this scenario has been organized as a sort of orchestration mechanism, invoking a number of other template files, each one responsible for part of the required deployment activities.

trans-unit.source: In particular, the following linked templates will be used for this deployment:
trans-unit.target: In particular, the following linked templates will be used for this deployment:

trans-unit.source: Shared-resource.json: Contains the definition of all resources that will be shared across the deployment.
trans-unit.target: Shared-resource.json: Contains the definition of all resources that will be shared across the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Examples are storage accounts used to store VM’s OS disks and virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: Examples are storage accounts used to store VM’s OS disks and virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: Jumpbox-resources.json: When enabled, is responsible for deploying all resources related to the Jumpbox VM, the one with a public IP address that can be used to access MongoDB cluster from public network.
trans-unit.target: Jumpbox-resources.json: When enabled, is responsible for deploying all resources related to the Jumpbox VM, the one with a public IP address that can be used to access MongoDB cluster from public network.

trans-unit.source: Arbiter-resources.json: When enabled, this template deploys an arbiter member in the MongoDB cluster.
trans-unit.target: Arbiter-resources.json: When enabled, this template deploys an arbiter member in the MongoDB cluster.

trans-unit.source: An arbiter doesn’t contain data, but is used when a replica set contains an even number of nodes to manage primary elections.
trans-unit.target: An arbiter doesn’t contain data, but is used when a replica set contains an even number of nodes to manage primary elections.

trans-unit.source: Member-resources-Dx.json: Specifies resource templates that are effectively deploying MongoDB nodes.
trans-unit.target: Member-resources-Dx.json: Specifies resource templates that are effectively deploying MongoDB nodes.

trans-unit.source: A specific file will be used based on the selected t-shirt size definition, where each file will only differ by the number of attached disks for each node.
trans-unit.target: A specific file will be used based on the selected t-shirt size definition, where each file will only differ by the number of attached disks for each node.

trans-unit.source: Mongodb-ubuntu-install.sh: A bash script file invoked by CustomScriptForLinux extension on every node in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Mongodb-ubuntu-install.sh: A bash script file invoked by CustomScriptForLinux extension on every node in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Responsible for mounting and formatting data disks, and installing MongoDB bits on the node.
trans-unit.target: Responsible for mounting and formatting data disks, and installing MongoDB bits on the node.

trans-unit.source: To deploy a MongoDB cluster, a specific logic is required to be able to correctly set up a replica set.
trans-unit.target: To deploy a MongoDB cluster, a specific logic is required to be able to correctly set up a replica set.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the specific sequence you have to use during the deployment.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the specific sequence you have to use during the deployment.

trans-unit.source: DEPLOY DATA MEMBERS (in parallel) => DEPLOY LAST DATA MEMBER => (optional) DEPLOY ARBITER
trans-unit.target: DEPLOY DATA MEMBERS (in parallel) => DEPLOY LAST DATA MEMBER => (optional) DEPLOY ARBITER

trans-unit.source: In this sequence, deploying multiple data nodes will happen in parallel, with the exception of the last node.
trans-unit.target: In this sequence, deploying multiple data nodes will happen in parallel, with the exception of the last node.

trans-unit.source: This is where the cluster will be formed and new replica set will be deployed, so all previous nodes will need to be up and running before that moment in time.
trans-unit.target: This is where the cluster will be formed and new replica set will be deployed, so all previous nodes will need to be up and running before that moment in time.

trans-unit.source: Last step will be to deploy the optional Arbiter node (only for those t-shirt sizes where this is required).
trans-unit.target: Last step will be to deploy the optional Arbiter node (only for those t-shirt sizes where this is required).

trans-unit.source: Looking again inside our main template (azuredeploy.json), let’s see how this logic is implemented, starting from all data members in the following example.
trans-unit.target: Looking again inside our main template (azuredeploy.json), let’s see how this logic is implemented, starting from all data members in the following example.

trans-unit.source: One important concept to highlight is how it is possible to deploy multiple copies of a single resource type, and for each instance can set unique values for required settings.
trans-unit.target: One important concept to highlight is how it is possible to deploy multiple copies of a single resource type, and for each instance can set unique values for required settings.

trans-unit.source: This concept is known as Resource Looping.
trans-unit.target: This concept is known as Resource Looping.

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, a parameter (number of nodes to deploy in the cluster) will be used to set a variable (“numberOfMembers”) which is then passed to the “copy” element to trigger a number (loop) of child deployments, each one will result in the instantiation of the template for each member in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the previous example, a parameter (number of nodes to deploy in the cluster) will be used to set a variable (“numberOfMembers”) which is then passed to the “copy” element to trigger a number (loop) of child deployments, each one will result in the instantiation of the template for each member in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: To be able to set all settings where unique values between instances are required, the copyindex() function can be used to obtain a numeric value indicating the current index in that particular resource loop creation.
trans-unit.target: To be able to set all settings where unique values between instances are required, the copyindex() function can be used to obtain a numeric value indicating the current index in that particular resource loop creation.

trans-unit.source: Another important concept in resource creation is the ability to specify dependencies and precedencies between resources, as you can notice in the dependsOn JSON array.
trans-unit.target: Another important concept in resource creation is the ability to specify dependencies and precedencies between resources, as you can notice in the dependsOn JSON array.

trans-unit.source: In this particular template, deploying each node depends on the previous successful deployment of shared resources.
trans-unit.target: In this particular template, deploying each node depends on the previous successful deployment of shared resources.

trans-unit.source: Attached disks are formatted as part of the node preparation activities triggered by the execution of the mongodb-ubuntu-install.sh script file.
trans-unit.target: Attached disks are formatted as part of the node preparation activities triggered by the execution of the mongodb-ubuntu-install.sh script file.

trans-unit.source: Inside that file, in fact you’ll find an instance of the following call.
trans-unit.target: Inside that file, in fact you’ll find an instance of the following call.

trans-unit.source: vm-disk-utils-0.1.sh is part of the shared_scripts\ubuntu folder, within the azure-quickstart-tempates Github repository, and contains very useful functions for disk mounting, formatting, and striping that can be reused every time you need to execute similar tasks as part of your template creation.
trans-unit.target: vm-disk-utils-0.1.sh is part of the shared_scripts\ubuntu folder, within the azure-quickstart-tempates Github repository, and contains very useful functions for disk mounting, formatting, and striping that can be reused every time you need to execute similar tasks as part of your template creation.

trans-unit.source: Another interesting fragment to explore, is the one related to CustomScriptForLinux VM extensions.
trans-unit.target: Another interesting fragment to explore, is the one related to CustomScriptForLinux VM extensions.

trans-unit.source: These are installed as a separate type of resource, with a dependency on each cluster node deployment template.
trans-unit.target: These are installed as a separate type of resource, with a dependency on each cluster node deployment template.

trans-unit.source: For example, see the following fragment at the end of each member-resources-Dx.json file.
trans-unit.target: For example, see the following fragment at the end of each member-resources-Dx.json file.

trans-unit.source: By familiarizing yourself with the other files included in this deployment, you will be able to understand all the details and best practices required to organize and orchestrate complex deployment strategies for multi-node solutions, based on any technology, leveraging Azure Resource Manager templates.
trans-unit.target: By familiarizing yourself with the other files included in this deployment, you will be able to understand all the details and best practices required to organize and orchestrate complex deployment strategies for multi-node solutions, based on any technology, leveraging Azure Resource Manager templates.

trans-unit.source: While not mandatory, a recommended approach is to structure your template files as shown in the following diagram.
trans-unit.target: While not mandatory, a recommended approach is to structure your template files as shown in the following diagram.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>mongodb-template-structure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>mongodb-template-structure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In essence, this approach suggests that you:
trans-unit.target: In essence, this approach suggests that you:

trans-unit.source: Define your core template file as a central orchestration point for all specific deployment activities, leveraging template linking to invoke sub template executions.
trans-unit.target: Define your core template file as a central orchestration point for all specific deployment activities, leveraging template linking to invoke sub template executions.

trans-unit.source: Create specific template files that will deploy all resources shared across all other specific deployment tasks (for example, storage accounts, vnet configuration, etc.).
trans-unit.target: Create specific template files that will deploy all resources shared across all other specific deployment tasks (for example, storage accounts, vnet configuration, etc.).

trans-unit.source: This can be heavily reused between deployments that have similar requirements in terms of common infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: This can be heavily reused between deployments that have similar requirements in terms of common infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Include optional resource templates for spot requirements specific of a given resource.
trans-unit.target: Include optional resource templates for spot requirements specific of a given resource.

trans-unit.source: For identical members of a group of resources (nodes in a cluster, etc.), create specific templates that leverage resource looping in order to deploy multiple instances with unique properties.
trans-unit.target: For identical members of a group of resources (nodes in a cluster, etc.), create specific templates that leverage resource looping in order to deploy multiple instances with unique properties.

trans-unit.source: For all post deployment tasks (for example, product installation, configurations, etc.), leverage script deployment extensions and create scripts specific to each technology.
trans-unit.target: For all post deployment tasks (for example, product installation, configurations, etc.), leverage script deployment extensions and create scripts specific to each technology.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.
